input.content:
You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
Professor Snape dislikes Harry Potter because of his popularity and fame. However, it was Snape himself that jump-started the boy’s fame.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In the Gift of the Magi the main characters sell their most treasured possessions to buy something for their spouse, only to discover that both gifts are mutually unusable.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In “Messy Room” by Shel Silverstein the speaker goes on about how messy a child’s room is. Then the poet reveals that the messy room's owner is himself.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In The Wizard of Oz Dorothy travels to the Wizard in order to get home, only to discover she had the power to get home all along, while the other characters ask for things they already possess like courage and brains.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In The Story of an Hour by Kate Chopin the main character believes that her husband has died. She starts to imagine what this new freedom will look like. She returns home in an hour and finds him alive and well. This surprises her as well as the reader.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Great Expectations Pip has a secret benefactor. Neither Pip nor the reader know who it is. The story makes it seem that the benefactor is Miss Havisham. Magwich, the true benefactor, is revealed clashing with the beliefs of both the audience and Pip.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
A Modest Proposal starts by advocating for the poor children of America. But he gradually implies that healthy children make better eating.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
Pride and Prejudice opens with, "It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession of a good fortune, must be in want of a wife."

1) situational irony

3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
The Rime of the Ancient Mariner, "Water, water, everywhere, nor any drop to drink,"

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Julius Caesar Mark Antony says, “But Brutus says he was ambitious, And Brutus is an honorable man.” Antony, however, is implying that Brutus isn't ambitious nor honorable.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In The Cask of Amontillado Fortunato is being led to his death by an acquaintance, Montresor. Montresor comments on Fortunato’s cough, to which he replies "I shall not die of a cough." This is true because Montresor intends to kill Fortunato.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
Lemony Snicket: An Unauthorized Autobiography, "Today was a very cold and bitter day, as cold and bitter as a cup of hot chocolate if the cup of hot chocolate had vinegar added to it and were placed in a refrigerator for several hours."

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Pygmalion, Professor Higgins says, "I swear! I never swear. I detest the habit. What the devil do you mean?"

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Romeo And Juliet, Romeo thinks Juliet is dead. The audience knows she is just sedated while Romeo proceeds to kill himself.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Macbeth, Duncan expresses his trust in Macbeth but the audience knows better. The king says, "He was a gentleman on whom I built an absolute trust" making the audience squirm.

1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Othello, Iago manipulates the Othello while the deception is plain to the audience.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In Oedipus Rex, Oedipus attempts to expose the murderer of King Laius. Oedipus himself, unknowingly, is the killer. He doesn't know but the reader does.

You will be presented with an example of irony. Determine the type of irony. Types of irony:
1) situational irony
2) verbal irony
3) dramatic irony
Answer with situational, verbal, or dramatic. Do not explain the answer. Answer with a single word, lower case, no period, no punctuation.

Here's the example:
In A Doll’s House, Nora trys to attain her freedom by paying a debt. However, the reader can plainly see that the freedom Nora wants is a type of bondage.
